item.title: Adaptive Trust Consensus for Blockchain IoT: Comparing RL, DRL, and MARL Against Naive, Collusive, Adaptive, Byzantine, and Sleeper Attacks
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes a trust-based delegated consensus framework for blockchain-enabled IoT that uses Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) and Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC) for privacy-preserving policy evaluation.
  • Systematically compares three learning-based defenses—tabular Q-learning (RL), Dueling Double DQN (DRL), and Multi-Agent RL (MARL)—against five attack families (Naive Malicious, Collusive Rumor, Adaptive Adversarial, Byzantine Fault Injection, Time-Delayed Poisoning) in a 16-node simulated IoT network.
  • Findings: MARL best defends against collusive attacks (F1=0.85 vs DRL 0.68, RL 0.50); DRL and MARL perfectly detect adaptive attacks (F1=1.00) while RL fails; all agents handle Byzantine attacks; Time-Delayed Poisoning (sleeper) catastrophically reduces detection (F1≈0.11–0.16), revealing a severe remaining vulnerability.

Paper Type

  • Research
